author: Edward Kenway

text:
@TheMostBleedingHeart I don't get how people say Pokemon is repetitive when it incorporates new graphical styles, gameplay mechanics, characters (humans and Pokemon), plots, and settings every game. Sure, it maintains a similar gameplay style to its predecessors, but it's no more repetitive in this fashion than most RPG games or sequels within a series. If you take any games of different generations, even ones with only a one generation difference, and compare the gameplay, there's hardly any repetition in them. I've found each generation has massive differences in the game experience, and while each game has mostly retained its appeal and resisted the "aged badly" effect, each generation has had major improvements on the previous.
...Given, Diamond and Pearl kind of sucked, but Platinum fixed all of the major issues with that and is honestly a phenomenal game.
I do really want to hear your opinion, though. What makes it too repetitive? I've always found that it maintains the core gameplay and functional environment to showcase it very well while changing the game enough to create fresh experiences and major differentiation.
...Also, in anticipation of a possible "same thing every time catch Pokemon battle gyms" argument, there are a ridiculous amount of spin-offs that are completely different from that kind of gameplay (Ranger, Conquest, Mystery Dungeon, Rumble, etc). If you're looking for a different approach to the Pokemon series, you could always try those. In my opinion, the main series is the MAIN series for a reason, and should maintain the Pokemon series-style gameplay while the spin-off games should have the change in style that some people ask for.
author: Query

text:
Did you even read my comment???
None of the spin off games are like that at all.
If someone complained about Metroid for being a robo suit lady who explores planets and fights aliens and stuff, that'd be the exact same thing.
Games in a series should share a common theme, and often common gameplay. Spin-offs and side series are for changing those.
Someone didn't hit read more.

author: XxMrGenoxX

text: @Tezcatlepocatl The way I see it is that N64 may have had some of the best games, but it had very few of them.  Not a lot of developers worked with Nintendo in the N64 days, since Sony had over a year of a head start in the market, and used discs.  The result was a few great games, and a lot of bad ones, and not a lot of in betweens.  6, maybe 7 of my top 20 games of all time were on Gamecube.  I'd be generous to fit more than 2 N64 on the list.  That's just my opinion, though =P

text:
I disagree. While there hasn't been any more real violence (or rather, the same violence) consider the timeline in stories:

First few games: kill all the Metroids and defeat Mother Brain.
Metroid Prime: stop the corruption and destruction of the last home of the Chozo by Space Pirates.
MP2: End a War between the two halves of Aether.
MP3: Fight a war with the Space Pirates, fight your allies, and prevent galatic corruption, while dealing with your own.

From exterminator to Galactic war.
